div1.p: Hanson is working on a report covering the Peruvian campaign.

div1.head: Excerpt of letter from Henry Hanson to Florence M. Read, August 4, 1921
div1.p:
Excerpt of letter to Miss Florence Read from Henry Hanson, Chiclayo, Peru,
August 4, 1921.

We are working up a very full report on the whole campaign, and I
believe we will get it up in a very graphic form as well. I have considered
the expense of this justified in that I think this is going to be the last
yellow fever campaign on this coast for a few centuries to come, and it ought
to be properly recorded. Dr. White will bring up an illustrated charts of what
has been a little less than one fifth of the entire campaign so from that you
will be able to judge what we have had on our hands.

Next week we will begin the final clean up of Ferrenafe, and when that is
done we will have the watching of the coast to see that the stegomyia index is
not allowed to rise until we are certain that there is nothing “lurking in the
bush”. We have everything else to the north of the Department of Ancash
down to less than three percent and most of it is about one percent of breeding
In many places it is even less.

In my last letter to Mr. Kirk and also to Dr. Rose I told of having
started prophylactic work in the Department of Ancash as a means of guarding
against the spread of the epidemic south. This work will continue until we
are sure of the conditions up here in the north. Fortunately all the news
lately from the south have been good news. Today I received a telegram from
Dr. Caballero who has made a series of investigations in Lima in the Hospitals
in which he states that he has been unable to find any reliable reports of the
existence of cases in Lima. Dr. Mendoza also went to Lima for the Centennial
and also is investigating for any suspicious case or history of case which
might have gotten by. So far none have been reported from my own men, which
makes me feel happier.
